verses.text: My son, if you accept my words and treasure up my commandments within you,
verses.comment: The language of filial relationship highlights wisdom’s transmission through authoritative teaching. 'Commandments' echoes themes of the Law and direct moral formation.

verses.text: making your ear attentive to wisdom and inclining your heart to understanding;
verses.comment: Wisdom involves both listening (obedience) and the inward movement of the heart, suggesting a full dedication to God's guidance.

verses.text: yes, if you call out for insight and lift up your voice for understanding,
verses.comment: Actively seeking wisdom through prayer and supplication underlines man's need for divine assistance (cf. James 1:5).

verses.text: if you seek it like silver and search for it as for hidden treasures,
verses.comment: The metaphor of treasure points to the surpassing value of wisdom, prefiguring Christ as the hidden treasure of faith.

verses.text: then you will understand the fear of the LORD and find the knowledge of God.
verses.comment: 'Fear of the Lord' marks the true beginning of wisdom and relationship with God, and foreshadows authentic reverence and worship.

verses.text: For the LORD gives wisdom; from his mouth come knowledge and understanding.
verses.comment: True wisdom comes as a gift from God, reminiscent of the Spirit’s illumination promised in the New Testament.

verses.text: He stores up sound wisdom for the upright; he is a shield to those who walk in integrity,
verses.comment: God’s protection is linked with moral uprightness, a theme developed in the New Testament's call to holiness.

verses.text: guarding the paths of justice and watching over the way of his faithful ones.
verses.comment: God's active watchfulness affirms His providential care for the just, foreshadowing the church’s teaching on perseverance.

verses.text: Then you will understand righteousness and justice and fairness—every good path.
verses.comment: Wisdom leads into living justly, echoing the moral law and the path of sanctification.

verses.text: For wisdom will come into your heart, and knowledge will be pleasant to your soul;
verses.comment: The indwelling of wisdom foreshadows the internal transformation by grace described in Romans 12:2.

verses.text: discretion will watch over you, understanding will guard you,
verses.comment: Spiritual virtues provide active protection against corrupt influence, a theme reinforced by warnings in the epistles.

verses.text: delivering you from the way of evil, from men of perverse speech,
verses.comment: Wisdom’s function as deliverance links to Christ as the Redeemer who frees from both error and sin.

verses.text: who leave the paths of uprightness to walk in the ways of darkness;
verses.comment: Light versus darkness is a strong theme in both testaments, ultimately fulfilled in Christ's coming as the light of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: who rejoice in doing evil and delight in the perverseness of wickedness,
verses.comment: Sin’s attraction is described as celebration of evil, paralleling Paul's exposition of mankind's fallen nature.

verses.text: men whose paths are crooked and who are devious in their ways.
verses.comment: 'Crooked' paths are contrasted with the straight way, which later becomes symbolic of the way of salvation.

verses.text: So you will be delivered from the strange woman, from the adulteress with her smooth words,
verses.comment: The 'strange woman' is personal and symbolic: of unfaithfulness to the covenant, a motif renewed in Revelation regarding the spiritual harlot.

verses.text: who forsakes the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God;
verses.comment: Faithlessness to marriage echoes faithfulness required in the new covenant—note the persistent theme of covenantal fidelity.

verses.text: for her house sinks down to death, and her paths to the spirits of the dead;
verses.comment: The consequences of spiritual and moral infidelity are grave, foreshadowing warnings about the eternal consequences of sin.

verses.text: none who go to her return, nor do they regain the paths of life.
verses.comment: The seeming finality references the reality of spiritual death, yet later texts reveal hope in redemption through grace.

verses.text: So you will walk in the way of good men and keep to the paths of the righteous.
verses.comment: The community of the righteous recalls the fellowship of believers, the spiritual family found in the gathered body of the faithful.

verses.text: For the upright will inhabit the land, and those with integrity will remain in it;
verses.comment: The promise of dwelling in the land links to the beatitudes ('inherit the earth'), symbolizing entrance into the eternal kingdom.

verses.text: but the wicked will be cut off from the land, and those who are unfaithful will be uprooted from it.
verses.comment: Final separation of the wicked signals both temporal judgment and eschatological fulfillment, foreshadowing the New Testament’s teaching on judgment and purgation.
